title: Stroke vs TIA Assessment
pcr_text: 65-year-old male with sudden left-sided weakness and slurred speech. Symptoms began 30 minutes ago. Is this a stroke or TIA?
correct_error: Stroke vs TIA: TIA symptoms resolve within 24 hours, stroke symptoms persist per neurology protocols.

options.text: Stroke - symptoms persist beyond 24 hours, requires immediate transport
TIA - symptoms will resolve, can wait for primary care
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Persistent symptoms = stroke requiring immediate ED evaluation.

options.text: Migraine headache - give pain medication

title: Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale - Facial Droop
pcr_text: 75-year-old female with facial asymmetry. Testing Cincinnati Stroke Scale: 'Show me your teeth' - one side of face doesn't move. What does this indicate?
correct_error: Cincinnati Scale facial droop: abnormal facial movement indicates stroke per neurology protocols.

options.text: Abnormal - facial droop present, positive stroke scale finding
Normal - facial asymmetry is common in elderly
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Facial droop on Cincinnati Scale = abnormal, indicates stroke.

options.text: Bell's palsy - not a stroke

title: Hypoglycemia Mimicking Stroke
pcr_text: 50-year-old diabetic with sudden confusion, right-sided weakness, blood glucose 45 mg/dL. Is this stroke or hypoglycemia?
correct_error: Hypoglycemia mimics stroke: check blood glucose first per endocrinology protocols.

options.text: Hypoglycemia - administer glucose, symptoms should resolve
Stroke - transport immediately without glucose
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Hypoglycemia can perfectly mimic stroke. Check glucose first.

options.text: Both - treat glucose and transport for stroke

title: DKA - Fruity Breath and Kussmaul
pcr_text: 25-year-old Type 1 diabetic with fruity breath odor, deep rapid breathing, blood glucose 550 mg/dL. What condition is this?
correct_error: DKA: fruity breath (acetone), Kussmaul respirations, hyperglycemia per endocrinology protocols.

options.text: Diabetic ketoacidosis - fruity breath, Kussmaul respirations, hyperglycemia
Insulin overdose - hypoglycemia would be present
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Fruity breath and hyperglycemia = DKA, not insulin shock.

options.text: Pneumonia - fruity breath indicates infection

title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm - Pulsating Mass
pcr_text: 80-year-old male with severe abdominal pain, palpable pulsating mass in abdomen. Should you palpate the mass?
correct_error: AAA: pulsating abdominal mass - DO NOT PALPATE, can rupture per GI protocols.

options.text: Do not palpate - risk of rupture, transport immediately
Gently palpate to confirm diagnosis
options.feedback: DANGEROUS! Palpating AAA can cause rupture. Do not touch!

options.text: Apply pressure to stop bleeding

title: Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale - Arm Drift
pcr_text: 60-year-old male with weakness. Testing Cincinnati Scale: 'Close your eyes and hold arms out' - left arm drifts down. What does this indicate?
correct_error: Cincinnati Scale arm drift: abnormal motor function indicates stroke per neurology protocols.

options.text: Abnormal - arm drift present, positive stroke scale finding
Normal - arm drift can occur in fatigue
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Arm drift on Cincinnati Scale = abnormal, indicates stroke.

options.text: Parkinson's disease - not a stroke

title: Insulin Shock vs DKA
pcr_text: 35-year-old diabetic found unconscious, shallow breathing, blood glucose 35 mg/dL, no fruity breath. Insulin shock or DKA?
correct_error: Insulin shock: hypoglycemia, no Kussmaul respirations, no fruity breath per endocrinology protocols.

options.text: Insulin shock - administer glucose immediately
DKA - requires IV fluids and insulin
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Hypoglycemia without fruity breath = insulin shock, not DKA.

options.text: Both - treat with glucagon and fluids

title: Appendicitis Assessment
pcr_text: 18-year-old male with right lower quadrant pain, nausea, low-grade fever, pain worse with movement. What is suspected?
correct_error: Appendicitis: RLQ pain, nausea, fever, pain with movement per GI protocols.

options.text: Appendicitis - transport immediately, no oral intake
Gastritis - give antacids and observe
options.feedback: INCORRECT! RLQ pain with fever and guarding = appendicitis requiring surgery.

options.text: Kidney stones - pain is flank, not RLQ

title: GI Bleed - Coffee Ground Emesis
pcr_text: 55-year-old male vomiting dark brown, grainy material that looks like coffee grounds. What does this indicate?
correct_error: Coffee ground emesis: digested blood from upper GI bleed per GI protocols.

options.text: Upper GI bleed - digested blood, transport immediately
Coffee ingestion - normal appearance
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Coffee ground emesis = upper GI bleeding requiring urgent care.

options.text: Bile reflux - green fluid expected

title: Autism - Sensory Overload Response
pcr_text: 14-year-old autistic patient having meltdown in chaotic scene, covering ears and rocking. What is the best approach?
correct_error: Autism sensory overload: reduce stimuli, allow coping mechanisms per special populations protocols.

options.text: Reduce sensory input and allow self-soothing behaviors
Physically restrain to prevent self-injury
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Restraint increases agitation. Use de-escalation techniques.

options.text: Administer sedative medication

title: Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale - Speech
pcr_text: 70-year-old female with slurred speech. Testing Cincinnati Scale: 'You know how to say the name of this object?' - patient unable to repeat correctly. What does this indicate?
correct_error: Cincinnati Scale abnormal speech: indicates stroke per neurology protocols.

options.text: Abnormal - speech deficit present, positive stroke scale finding
Normal - speech can be slurred in elderly
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Abnormal speech on Cincinnati Scale = positive finding for stroke.

options.text: Dementia - not acute stroke

title: LVAD Patient - Normal Assessment
pcr_text: 45-year-old LVAD patient presents with chest pain. Device is humming normally. Should you expect a pulse?
correct_error: LVAD patients: no palpable pulse is normal, device maintains circulation per special populations protocols.

options.text: No palpable pulse is normal - LVAD maintains circulation
Absence of pulse indicates cardiac arrest
options.feedback: INCORRECT! LVAD patients often have no palpable pulse. Assess mentation and perfusion.

options.text: Check for pulse on both sides

title: Dialysis Patient - Shunt Bleeding
pcr_text: 65-year-old dialysis patient with bright red blood soaking through dressing on arm shunt. How should you control bleeding?
correct_error: Dialysis shunt bleeding: apply direct pressure only, do not use tourniquet per special populations protocols.

options.text: Apply direct pressure with gloved hand
Apply tourniquet proximal to shunt
options.feedback: DANGEROUS! Tourniquets can damage shunt. Use direct pressure only.

options.text: Elevate arm above heart

title: Build-a-List: Seizure Management Steps
pcr_text: 30-year-old male having tonic-clonic seizure. Order the management steps:
correct_error: Seizure management sequence: protect head, clear area, recovery position per neurology protocols.

options.text: 1. Protect head from injury, 2. Clear area of hazards, 3. Place in recovery position after seizure stops, 4. Transport if indicated
1. Administer diazepam, 2. Protect head, 3. Clear area
options.feedback: INCORRECT ORDER! EMT-B cannot administer benzodiazepines. Protect head first.

options.text: 1. Clear area, 2. Recovery position, 3. Protect head

title: DKA - Kussmaul Respirations
pcr_text: 22-year-old diabetic with deep, rapid breathing pattern, fruity breath, altered mental status. What breathing pattern is this?
correct_error: Kussmaul respirations: deep rapid breathing in DKA to compensate for acidosis per endocrinology protocols.

options.text: Kussmaul respirations - deep and rapid in DKA
Cheyne-Stokes - irregular in brain injury
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Deep, rapid breathing with fruity breath = Kussmaul in DKA.

options.text: Apneustic - prolonged inspiration in brainstem injury

title: Stroke - Time Last Known Normal
pcr_text: 55-year-old female found with left-sided weakness. Family reports she was normal this morning. What time was she last known normal?
correct_error: Stroke time criteria: last known normal time determines TPA eligibility per neurology protocols.

options.text: This morning - within time window for potential intervention
Yesterday - outside time window for acute treatment
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Time last normal determines treatment eligibility. Document accurately.

options.text: Unknown - cannot determine stroke timing

title: Build-a-List: CPAP Application Steps
pcr_text: 75-year-old male with severe respiratory distress, oxygen saturation 85%. Order the CPAP application steps:
correct_error: CPAP application sequence: assess, explain, apply, monitor per respiratory protocols.

options.text: 1. Assess contraindications, 2. Explain procedure, 3. Apply mask and initiate low pressure, 4. Titrate pressure, 5. Monitor response
1. Apply mask, 2. Turn on high pressure, 3. Monitor saturation
options.feedback: INCORRECT ORDER! Assess contraindications first, start low pressure.

options.text: 1. Explain procedure, 2. Apply mask, 3. High pressure immediately

title: Hypoglycemia - Altered Mental Status
pcr_text: 40-year-old diabetic confused and combative, blood glucose 42 mg/dL. Should you treat as behavioral or medical?
correct_error: Hypoglycemia can mimic psychiatric emergency: check glucose first per endocrinology protocols.

options.text: Medical emergency - administer glucose immediately
Psychiatric emergency - restrain and transport
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Hypoglycemia perfectly mimics psychiatric symptoms. Check glucose first.

options.text: Both - give glucose and sedate

title: GI Bleed - Bright Red Blood
pcr_text: 45-year-old male vomiting bright red blood, dizzy and pale. What type of GI bleed is this?
correct_error: Hematemesis: bright red blood indicates active upper GI bleed per GI protocols.

options.text: Upper GI bleed - bright red blood from esophagus/stomach
Lower GI bleed - dark tarry stools expected
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Bright red vomited blood = upper GI bleed (hematemesis).

options.text: Nosebleed - blood from nasopharynx

title: Autism - Communication Assessment
pcr_text: 16-year-old autistic patient in pain but nonverbal. How do you assess pain level?
correct_error: Autism pain assessment: observe behavioral indicators, use nonverbal scales per special populations protocols.

options.text: Observe behavioral cues and use nonverbal pain assessment
Use standard 1-10 verbal pain scale
options.feedback: INEFFECTIVE! Autistic patients may not communicate pain verbally. Use behavioral assessment.

options.text: Assume no pain since patient can't verbalize

title: Build-a-List: Seizure Management - Post-Ictal
pcr_text: 25-year-old female post-seizure, confused and disoriented. Order the post-ictal care steps:
correct_error: Post-ictal care sequence: ensure safety, recovery position, assess ABCs per neurology protocols.

options.text: 1. Ensure scene safety, 2. Place in recovery position, 3. Assess ABCs, 4. Monitor for recurrence, 5. Transport if indicated
1. Administer oxygen, 2. Restrain patient, 3. Recovery position
options.feedback: INCORRECT ORDER! Recovery position first, then assess ABCs. No restraint.

options.text: 1. Recovery position, 2. Oxygen, 3. Transport immediately

title: LVAD Patient - Alarm Response
pcr_text: 50-year-old LVAD patient with device alarm sounding 'low flow'. Patient is alert but tachycardic. What should you do?
correct_error: LVAD alarm: do not attempt manual CPR, focus on device function per special populations protocols.

options.text: Check device connections and power source
Begin manual CPR immediately
options.feedback: INEFFECTIVE! LVAD maintains circulation. Address device issues first.

options.text: Disconnect device and defibrillate

title: Dialysis Patient - Access Complications
pcr_text: 70-year-old dialysis patient with swollen, painful arm at fistula site, low-grade fever. What is suspected?
correct_error: Dialysis fistula infection: redness, swelling, fever at access site per special populations protocols.

options.text: Fistula infection - transport immediately, no BP in affected arm
Normal post-dialysis swelling - observe at scene
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Red, swollen, painful fistula with fever = infection requiring IV antibiotics.

options.text: Deep vein thrombosis - elevate arm

title: Build-a-List: CPAP Troubleshooting
pcr_text: 60-year-old male on CPAP with persistent low oxygen saturation. Order the troubleshooting steps:
correct_error: CPAP troubleshooting sequence: check mask fit, increase pressure, assess patient per respiratory protocols.

options.text: 1. Check mask fit and seal, 2. Adjust head strap, 3. Increase pressure gradually, 4. Assess for contraindications, 5. Consider alternative oxygenation
1. Increase pressure to maximum, 2. Check mask, 3. Remove CPAP
options.feedback: INCORRECT ORDER! Check fit first, increase pressure gradually.

options.text: 1. Remove mask, 2. Increase pressure, 3. Reapply mask

title: Stroke Mimic - Complex Migraine
pcr_text: 35-year-old female with sudden headache, visual changes, left-sided numbness. History of migraines. Stroke or migraine?
correct_error: Stroke mimics: migraines can present with focal neurological symptoms per neurology protocols.

options.text: Cannot rule out stroke - transport for CT scan
Complex migraine - give pain medication and observe
options.feedback: INCORRECT! New neurological symptoms require stroke rule-out, even with migraine history.

options.text: Tension headache - not neurological

title: DKA - Treatment Priority
pcr_text: 19-year-old diabetic in DKA, altered mental status, deep respirations. What is the immediate treatment priority?
correct_error: DKA treatment: IV fluids most critical, insulin secondary per endocrinology protocols.

options.text: IV fluid resuscitation - correct dehydration first
Insulin administration - correct hyperglycemia
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Fluids are priority in DKA. Insulin can be given after fluid bolus.

options.text: Sodium bicarbonate - correct acidosis

title: Build-a-List: Seizure First Aid
pcr_text: 20-year-old male experiencing first seizure. Order the immediate first aid steps:
correct_error: Seizure first aid sequence: protect patient, time seizure, recovery position per neurology protocols.

options.text: 1. Protect head, 2. Clear area, 3. Time seizure duration, 4. Recovery position after, 5. Assess ABCs
1. Put finger in mouth, 2. Hold down, 3. Recovery position
options.feedback: INCORRECT ORDER! Never put anything in mouth. Protect head and time seizure.

options.text: 1. Recovery position, 2. Clear area, 3. Protect head

hazards.action: Do not restrain or insert objects
